October 19,1986: Fiction
IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a
woman who grew up in a small Maine town.
RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear
weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III.
HOLLYWOOD HUSBANDS, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A top
New York model encounters three of Los Angeles's most dynamic men.
WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A rich orphan comes of
age while she travels the world.
THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) The complex
relationships of families in New York City and South Carolina's low country.
THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. (Random House, $19.95.)
Romance, family conflict, power and greed mark a young woman's life in 18th-
century England and France.
ROGER'S VERSION, by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) A fiftyish professor
wrestles with God, sex, science, technology, mathematics and computers.
THE BEET QUEEN, by Louise Erdrich. (Holt, $16.95.) Forty years of life in a small
North Dakota town near an Indian reservation.
THE GOLDEN CUP, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Continuing the saga of a
turn-of-the-century New York family begun in ''Evergreen.''
A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.)
Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could change the course of the cold war.
LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $17.95.) The adventures of a
United States Air Force major in Siberia.
FOUNDATION AND EARTH, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $16.95.) In the fifth
volume of the ''Foundation'' series, the hero continues his search for the lost
planet Earth.
REGRETS ONLY, by Sally Quinn. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Two women, two
men, passion and power brokering in Washington.
THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A woman's
attachment to her daughter presents her with a dilemma.
THE WILD BLUE, by Walter J. Boyne and Steven L. Thompson. (Crown, $19.95.)
Six members of the Air Force at work, at play and in love.
October 19, 1986
Non-Fiction
HIS WAY, by Kitty Kelley. (Bantam, $21.95.) From Hoboken to superstardom: an
unauthorized biography of Frank Sinatra.
FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and
ruminations from the television star and father of five.
MAYFLOWER MADAM, by Sydney Biddle Barrows with William Novak. (Arbor
House, $17.95.) A member of one of America's oldest families tells of the world's
oldest profession.
YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at
the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme.
MCMAHON! by Jim McMahon with Bob Verdi. (Warner, $16.95.) The
autobiography of the quarterback for the Chicago Bears.
THE STORY OF ENGLISH, by Robert McCrum, William Cran and Robert
MacNeil. (Sifton/Viking, $24.95.) Companion volume to the PBS series about the
world's most widely used language.
SNAKE, by Ken Stabler and Berry Stainback. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The
experiences of the retired Oakland Raiders quarterback.
ONE KNEE EQUALS TWO FEET, by John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Villard,
$16.95.) Observations on football by the television commentator and former
Oakland Raiders coach.
NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a
series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow.
JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.)
Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal.
I, TINA, by Tina Turner with Kurt Loder. (Morrow, $16.95.) The autobiography of a
Tennessee sharecropper's daughter who became a rock-and-roll star.
EISENHOWER AT WAR 1943-1945, by David Eisenhower. (Random House,
$29.95.) How fighting a coalition war from 1943 to 1945 developed the general's
political acumen.
STAR WOMAN, by Lynn V. Andrews. (Warner, $16.95.) A quest for self-discovery,
aided by an American Indian medicine woman.
THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $19.95.) The crisis in the
American automobile industry and Japan's role in it.
MY DADDY WAS A PISTOL AND I'M A SON OF A GUN, by Lewis Grizzard.
